text:
To Whom It May Concern:
Maintaining net neutrality is important and vital for the functioning of free speech
and protection of individual freedoms. The FCC is supposed to regulate national 
communication systems, not hand deliver complete control to the sole authority of 
private corporations. Removing net neutrality is merely evidence of the failure of 
politics, bureaucracy, and creates a corrupt system. 
I fail to understand how creating a two tier system can in any way be fair or legal.
The FCC is not only failing to protect the consumer, it is actually countering its 
own mandate. 
There needs to be a logical-government sanctioned (aka legal) reason for allowing 
the service provider to vary the speed, and therefore access, of different internet 
sites. Basically, we would be handing control of the internet to the corporations. 
There is no way such legislature can be passed.

Chairman Tom Wheeler

Federal Communications Commission
445 12th Street, SW

Washington, DC 20554

Re: WC Docket No. 14-28 Comments

As an Internet user who believes strongly in the importance of a free and open Internet, I urge the
FCC to reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, and save Net
Neutrality. In addition, the FCC should reject the proposed rules that would allow Internet service
providers to divide the Internet into fast lanes for wealthy corporations and slow lanes for the rest of
us.

Sincerely,

Paul Baker
1605 Hammel Rd
Eagle Point, OR 97524-7714

CREDO Action

May 6, 2014
Chairman Tom Wheeler
Dear Chairman Wheeler,
As an Illinois consumer who depends on a fast, affordable web
connection, I am concerned that a free and open Internet is now in
grave danger.
We are troubled by reports that the Federal Communications Commission
(FCC) plans to propose new rules that would open the door for big
Internet providers to offer a "fast lane" to the highest
bidders. Such a proposal would water down consumer protections, serve
as a slippery slope to discrimination against certain web traffic, and
force consumers like me to suffer higher rates and slower speeds.
That violates the spirit of "net neutrality."
Please, stand up for consumers, protect net neutrality, and fight for
the free and open Internet.
Sincerely,
Ms. Florence Sullivan
11239 S Artesian Ave
Chicago, IL 60655-1434
author: Various
email_subject: Protect the free and open Internet!

text:
Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

Is Washington even trying to hide the corruption anymore?  This filing is a huge 
conspiracy supported by those in power who have something to gain by becoming 
puppets to wealthy communications companies.  I would love to hear how this benefits
a consumer, the average American citizen, anyone besides a communications company.  
Tell me what the benefit is.  What problem is the FCC trying to solve?  There is no 
problem to solve.  This is an excuse for the government to mess up something that 
works perfectly now in order to line pockets of politicians by allowing corporations
to stomp all over private citizens for financial gain.  It's not right!  Solve 
problems like you were put in office to do.  Serve the public as the oath you swore 
declared that you would.

The internet was developed for all people. You selling out to Verizon, AT&T, and 
Comcast will destroy that. Judas sold Christ out for 30 pieces of silver. How much 
did you get?

Chairman Tom Wheeler

Federal Communications Commission
445 12th Street, SW

Washington, DC 20554

Re: WC Docket No. 14-28 Comments

As an Internet user who believes strongly in the importance of a free and open Internet, I urge the
FCC to reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, and save Net
Neutrality. In addition, the FCC should reject the proposed rules that would allow Internet service
providers to divide the Internet into fast lanes for wealthy corporations and slow lanes for the rest of
us.

Sincerely,

Julie Robinson
1314 East 56th St
CHICAGO, IL 60637-1712

CREDO Action

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
The internet is a public utility. We can’t live with it and the economy certainly can’t function without it. It’s time to stop
 this “fast lanes” and “slow lanes” discussion and move to regulate the internet as a public utility.
Mario DeFazio
 07712
author: Various
email_subject: Let’s stop pretending that the internet is a “service”

text:
Its quite common that the name of a legislation is the exact opposite of what the 
legislation actually does, case in point, net neutrality. Leave the internet alone, 
as it's obvious this is just another step in the process of creating a tyrannical 
network of dictators that spreads across the whole world. Whilst you will not 
neccessarily care for the content of my message, please know that I am fully AGAINST
THIS LEGISLATION or anything that allows anyone control of the internet, especially 
those that work for the US Government.

I implore the FCC to stand with the citizens of this country, not the corporations, 
and protect our Net Neutrality. The ISPs in this country, many of them cable TV 
providers, hope to add to their profit margins by throttling internet traffic to 
their competitors, including Netflix and Hulu, unless their customers agree to 
paying premiums to reach those sites. The ISP offerings in many regions of this 
country already exhibit the qualities of a duopoly, or even worse, a monopoly. 
Ending the era of Net Neutrality will immediately halt one of the only sectors of 
our economy that is growing, and further strengthen the already firm stranglehold 
the duopoly laden ISP industry has on its customers.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
I urge you to protect the open internet by reclassifying broadband under Title II to protect Net neutrality, and by
scraping any proposed “pay-to-play” rule.
Net neutrality principles are essential to a 21st century internet. The FCC should protect the open internet and further,
treat it as a telecommunications service to disincentivize greedy ISPs from trying to extract additional fees from
consumers and web content creators.
Please protect real Net neutrality to ensure a thriving economy and democracy.
Sincerely,
Elizabeth Lott
 02148
author: Various

text:
I do not support the recent proceeding where it was discussed to allow Internet 
Service Providers to be able to allow certain companies faster access than others. 
Although the proposal right now would not make ISP's blatantly able to give 
non-paying customers slower access, this proposal seems to be going in the exact 
opposite direction that would benefit normal Americans that are the end user. 
Rather than opening a can of worms and going down a slippery  slope to potentially 
ruin net neutrality, the FCC that is an organization appointed by congress a 
publicly elected body, should be working steadfastly to ensure that the internet 
remains open and free for the average American.  Re-classify ISPs as a common 
carrier under Title II of the Communications act.   The internet is essential 
infrastructure for almost everybody. 
Thank you,

Dear FCC,
My name is Henry G Luken IV and I live in Soddy Daisy, TN.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because ISPs could act as the gatekeepers to their
subscribers.
Don't mess with what we love.
Sincerely,
Henry G Luken IV

competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and

The Internet is a platform where rural people can speak for themselves and on behalf
of their communities to wider audiences. Net Neutrality grants equal opportunity to 
every idea and helps ensure that rural communities do not experience the same lack 
of representation they have in other media platforms where rural voices are 
excluded.
Yet, 14.5 million rural Americans do not have access to broadband service. And 
allowing Internet providers to sell fast Internet lanes to those who can afford them
is like selling megaphones to the rich and leaving rural people without a voice.
To prohibit fast lanes and guarantee all American voices have full access to the 
Internet, the FCC must classify Internet service as a Title II Telecommunications 
Service.
FCC, don't silence rural communities! Reclassify Internet service as a Title II 
service and establish the strongest Network Neutrality rules possible. Net 
neutrality makes the Internet a vital platform for rural people to create and share 
our own images. Rural people working to present a genuine portrayal of America need 
Title II.

Dear FCC,
My name is Sean Phu and I live in Fountain Valley, CA.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The Internet is important to me because, as a college business student, I need to 
know that there will not be barriers to entry for the new ideas and services that I 
hope to bring to the marketplace. If ISP subscribers have an easier time loading 
websites of existing companies than my new innovative product, there?s no way that I
will be able to compete or succeed.
Sincerely,
Sean Phu

text:
Reclassify Internet Service Providers As Common Carriers.  
Net neutrality is vital to public communication and access to information.  It is 
also one of the few tools available to the customer to combat the monopolistic 
practices of the major internet providers.
Keep Net Neutrality alive so the internet stays friendly to new ideas.
We demand Free Speech, Net neutrality.  Protect the open internet!  Protect our right to information and gllobal communication!

Please do not let large corporations ruin the internet. Net neutrality only helps 
large companies. 
Please halt all progress on the proposal to end net neutrality, immediately!
You are not listening to the will of the people or the voices of those technology 
companies who truly understand what a terrible idea you proposal is to the Internet 
as we know it, rather than the corporate interests of the only people who stand to 
benefit from this awful proposal, the ISPs who would make more money by charging for
the so called "fast lane".
This proposal is in direct conflict with 3 of the stated goals of the FCC's 
strategic initiatives:
"All Americans should have affordable access to robust and reliable broadband 
products and services. Regulatory policies must promote technological neutrality, 
competition, investment, and innovation to ensure that broadband service providers 
have sufficient incentives to develop and offer such products and services."
"Competition in the provision of communication services, both domestically and 
overseas, supports the Nation's economy. The competitive framework for 
communications services should foster innovation and offer consumers reliable, 
meaningful choice in affordable services."
"The Nation's media regulations must promote competition and diversity and 
facilitate the transition to digital modes of delivery."If you do not halt this proposal and maintain net neutrality, I ask for you to step down from your position and resign and will demand your resignation to my elected representatives. This proposal is a slap to the face of everything good and wonderful that has been brought about in the modern technological and connected society thanks to the Internet, and a complete sell out to the corporate interests of the few, whom you used to lobby for.In fact, if a fair and honest world, you should not have ever been nominated to yourposition in the first place, given your background in corporate servitude to the companies you are now charged with regulating, as this is a HUGE conflict of interest.Sincerely,
C. Dresner

text:
The net should be free. big companies like comcast shouldn't be able to rule what 
goes through the connection and at what speed. They should just provide it.

Dear FCC,
My name is Joseph and I live in Statesboro, GA.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
Americans are supposed to live under a minimalist government that does nothing to 
discriminate based upon belief, speech, race, gender, sexual orientation or ECONOMIC
STATUS. People work their fingers to the bone to come to this country in part 
because we have the freedom to express ourselves as we wish and to have our voices 
heard, for better or worse. When the government bends to the pressure of business 
entities, whose only goal is to make as much money as possible with whatever damage 
the government will support or ignore, that government diminishes the freedoms of 
its people. 
By destroying "net neutrality", the FCC will diminish the capacity for new organizations to gain momentum. Ideas such as the "Scout" by Scanadu, a private company - which has put the power of physical examination in the hand of the layman and gives them better communication with their primary care provider - may never be allowed to flourish and improve the quality of living and the technological diversity of entire sectors of the market. Diminishing net neutrality will reduce the heterogeneity of one of the greatest constructs of human kind. No longer will the diminutive yet brilliant minds of so many small innovators be allowed their expression to be heard. No longer will true, individual talent be brought into the spotlight. People's content may not go viral. Their ideas may not be allowed to flourish. Fewer Americans will become successful entrepreneurs, entertainers and educators. 
The purpose of the government is to look out for the interests of the people. The many, not the few. When a government prioritizes big business over its people - those who fund its every move - that government fails in its purpose. 
If this is ever read by another being, I want them to do everything in their power to dissuade the FCC from this treacherous course of action. Keep the internet free and open to all who exercise their right to expression.
Thank you.
Sincerely,
Joseph

neutrality.
The Internet is a democratic medium.  It has grown exponentially, fueled innovation and altered how we communicate

Now, large, for-profit interests want to violate the principle of network neutrality in order to increase their own profit

text:
I support Net Neutrality, the First Amendment of the Internet. Access to the 
Internet is an invaluable commodity that should transcend socio-economics.  The 
American people and American companies are already dealing with local monopolies in 
getting access to the internet in the first place.   Allowing ISPs to auction off 
preferred access to companies who pay more runs counter to the free market 
philosophies on which America was founded. Before Tom Wheeler became Chairman of the
FCC, Tom Wheeler was a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industry, which the FCC 
is supposed to regulate. Not only is this a conflict of interest, Wheeler has 
repeatedly demonstrated that he is not working for the good of the American people. 
Thank you for your time in reading my comment.  I hope the FCC will stand up for the
good of American people on this issue.

text:
To Whom It May Concern:
Dear Sir or Madam,
Internet Neutrality is an incredibly important issue, and one that we feel strongly 
about. The freedom of information is a right we hold dear in America, and one that 
we must stand up for. Letting internet neutrality fall to the wayside means a loss 
of freedom we will not accept. As Thomas Jefferson said, "And are we to have a 
censor whose imprimatur shall say what books may be sold and what we may buy? Whose 
foot is to be the measure to which ours are all to be cut or stretched? Is a priest 
to be our inquisitor, or shall a layman, simple as ourselves, set up his reason as 
the rule for what we are to read and what we must believe? " Only in this case, will
we let money determine what we are and are not allowed to access? We don't believe 
that is acceptable or right. The internet must remain neutral.

The integrity of the internet relys on net neutrality. The current status of the 
internet is the only thing standing between a complete monopoly and modern era 
infested with a new breed of filth in america

Net neutrality is important to ensure a level playing field for all start ups. If 
the government does away with it, the public will have a choice between having to 
deal with slow connection speeds with companies who can't afford to pay a premium to
ensure a higher download speed or with higher speeds with the existing monopoly of 
providers. My internet bill is outrageous but the only option I have is DSL, which 
has extremely slow speeds. I'm totally against changing how we access the internet 
to give advantages to big corporations that will continue to conduct a monopoly 
system that has no advantage to anyone but their bottom line! Maintain Net 
Neutrality.

Chairman Tom Wheeler

Federal Communications Commission
445 12th Street, SW

Washington, DC 20554

Re: WC Docket No. 14-28 Comments

As an Internet user who believes strongly in the importance of a free and open Internet, I urge the
FCC to reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, and save Net
Neutrality. In addition, the FCC should reject the proposed rules that would allow Internet service
providers to divide the Internet into fast lanes for wealthy corporations and slow lanes for the rest of
us. It has been so wonderfully useful to be able to get what I need when I need it. Please don‘t take
it away and give it to the people who get the big tax breaks.

Sincerely,

Nancy Pyle
23088 State Hwy. 43
Daisy, OK 74540

CREDO Action

text:
Hello, I am a regular Internet user and enjoy using the Internet a lot. I received a
article about Net Neutrality. I have looked over the rules and do not like them one 
bit. These rules just tell you how badly and desperately these big name companies 
want more money, even if it means making the Internet for certain people that are 
against the company so SLOW. I really recommend, as an Internet user, to not pass 
these rules. I also request that the FCC reclassifies Internet service providers as 
title 2 common carriers.

As a resident of a rural area and the head strategist for a technology company, I am
deeply concerned about the de facto monopoly/duopoly power that ISPs wield in most 
areas, particularly rural ones. We are already seeing states and the federal 
government reduce requirements for telecom utilities to provide basic phone access 
in rural areas. If the FCC fails to make clear that ISPs are telecommunications 
service providers under Title II of the Communications Act, we will continue to see 
ISPs steadily increasing their rent-taking behavior as de facto monopolists, 
including lobbying against municipal broadband, imposing bandwidth caps, neglecting 
their infrastructure, and throttling traffic from vendors who fail to pay what are 
essentially kickbacks.
        
My worry is that this behavior will result in residents of my area and other rural 
areas being left behind in terms of lack of broadband options, decreased access to 
jobs that require high-throughput broadband, and decreased attractiveness to 
entrepreneurs looking for good locations to found companies. From my perspective as 
an IT strategist, I am concerned that we will face increasingly high fees for 
increasingly worse service from our ISPs and those that service our customers; 
moreover, our ability to hire the best employees will be constrained by the need for
those employees to reside in shrinking zones in which they can find an acceptable 
broadband provider. The US is being left behind the rest of the world in broadband penetration - the FCC has an opportunity here to call a spade a spade and classify ISPs as telecom services under Title II as they should have been from the beginning.

Dear FCC,
My name is Jacqueline Tillman and I live in East Falmouth, MA.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because ISPs could act as the gatekeepers to their
subscribers.
The Internet is important to me because, as a college business student, I need to 
know that there will not be barriers to entry for the new ideas and services that I 
hope to bring to the marketplace. If ISP subscribers have an easier time loading 
websites of existing companies than my new innovative product, there?s no way that I
will be able to compete or succeed.
Sincerely,
Jacqueline Tillman

Net neutrality allows for all businesses to compete on an even field, ultimately 
benefiting consumers.  Allowing cable and telecom providers to enable a tiered 
service model will reduce overall service to consumers and/or result in an increase 
in price for existing services delivered online due to companies forced to pay more 
for higher speed service to compete.  Please leave net neutrality alone!

Jacob Sorenson

text:
Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
I urge you to protect the open internet by reclassifying broadband under Title II to protect Net neutrality, and by
scraping any proposed “pay-to-play” rule.
Net neutrality principles are essential to a 21st century internet. The FCC should protect the open internet and further,
treat it as a telecommunications service to disincentivize greedy ISPs from trying to extract additional fees from
consumers and web content creators.
Please protect real Net neutrality to ensure a thriving economy and democracy.
Sincerely,
Craig Jones
 92019

text:
Dear FCC,
My name is Andrew Schmidt and I live in Saint Louis, MO.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because ISPs could act as the gatekeepers to their
subscribers.
Let's take a look at human history.  When people who already wield power are given 
more power, what do they do? Do they decide to use their power in the best interest 
of the people? Some do, like Bill Gates and Warren Buffet.  The problem is that I 
have trouble listing more than these two, and there are definitely more than two 
rich people on the planet.  The moral of the story is that people with power almost 
ALWAYS abuse this power for personal gain.  If you strike down net neutrality, then 
you're trusting the single least trustworthy caste with even more power than they 
already have.  WHEN HAS THIS EVER WORKED.  OPEN A HISTORY BOOK FOR CHRIST'S SAKE.  These laissez-faire policies sound great on paper but they're almost always bad for the people.  If you strike down the last bastion of decency and freedom, the internet, then you've proven whose side you're on.  Is that fancy dinner or nice carreally worth betraying the principles of freedom and equality? Will you be able to sleep at night knowing you had the chance to save democracy and instead sold us all out? Sold out a 17 year old kid going into college who was raised on the internet? Will you destroy my world?
Sincerely,
Andrew Schmidt

Keep the Internet equally accessible to all businesses and individuals.  Making it

at the same time.

 to the people, then we demand that you resign from your position as FCC Chairman, so someone who is willing to
listen to the people may take over.
This may just be one e-mail from one individual, but you can believe that I am nowhere near the only US citizen and

text:
I wish to express my support of net neutrality. I believe that allowing companies or
individuals to pay for prioritizing the transfer of data is a fundamental threat to 
democracy and free and fair competition in America. 
All internet traffic should be treated equally. This allows free competition for 
services and information and prevents certain companies from using their size and 
resources to secure an unfair monopoly. The internet is a great and transformative 
force that has been working extremely well. I urge you not to give in to the cable 
companies demands for the privilege of charging for tiers of service. It would 
destroy the internet as we know it and be a net negative for the people of America.
Thank you.
Reclassify The Internet As A Common Carrier.

As an American citizen, I wanted to voice my opposition to the FCC?s crippling new 
regulations that would put federal bureaucrats in charge of internet freedom, and 
urge you to stop these regulations before they?re enacted.
Our options for cheap, high-speed, high-performing internet providers will be 
severely limited, because of the large number of regulations dictated by the federal
government.
Like many Americans, I believe that the internet should remain free of government 
control and unnecessary regulation?just as it has for the last twenty years of 
unprecedented growth.
Please stop the FCC?s dangerous new regulations\, and protect the future of internet
freedom here in America.
Reclassify Internet Service Providers As Common Carriers.

The open internet has been one of the greatest economic boons of the modern age.  
Allowing ISPs even more control over this platform will be dentrimental to the 
Internet in every possible respect.  We are already losing business because of the 
rampant NSA spying, why further push away business by making such a stupid move.  I 
not only disagree with this proposal but I strongly suggest making ISPs a public 
utility to try and bring American internet speeds up to those of other developed 
nations.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
Net neutrality principles are of the utmost importance and anything violating open internet principles is unacceptable.
The FCC should use it’s authority to regulate the internet as a telecommunications service to protect consumers and
enshrine Net neutrality.
I am very concerned about any paid prioritization or proposed “pay-to-play” rule––destroying Net neutrality principles
is not an option. This new rule will change the nature of the equal and open internet, while creating real barriers to entry
that will stifle innovation.
Sincerely,
Ray Ables

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

The Internet has become necessary. I consider it a utility, the same as power and 
water. It must be regulated as such. Allowing private interests, such as Comcast, to
discriminate in any way the data they transmit undermines competition. These 
companies are near monopolies in their current form and maintaining Net Neutrality 
is imperative to maintaining competition. Please, I am requesting that the FCC 
reclassifies Internet Service Providers as Title II common carriers.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
The internet is a cornerstone of modern life -- from our day-to-day live to businesses and jobs. We simply can’t live
without it, so it’s time to declare that it is a public utility, not a private “service.”
May Barrell

is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

I	am	an	avid	supporter	of	the	free	market,	yet	I	see	only	cons	in	letting	service	
providers	limit	bandwidth	and	sell	enhanced	services.		Letting	service	providers	
have	such	control	will	lead	to	decreased	benefits	of	consumers	and	the	crippling	of	
potential	future	Internet	companies.		It	is	my	desire	that	the	FCC	governs	net	
neutrality	again	and	I	will	fight	with	my	representatives	until	the	law	is	corrected.

title 2 internet, why are you defying the will of the people.  Enough is enough.  
Stop destroying America. Tom wheeler you are a complete fraud and everyone in the 
country knows it.

text:
To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
In your upcoming NPRM rules I’m very concerned about any “pay-to-play” rule, destroying Net neutrality principles is
not acceptable. This new rule will change the nature of the equal and open internet, while creating real barriers to entry
that will prohibit innovation.
I ask that you ensure Net neutrality principles are of the utmost importance, and anything violating those principles is
unacceptable to the American public and dangerous to innovators. The FCC should use its authority to regulate the
internet as a telecommunications service to protect consumers and enshrine Net neutrality.
Sincerely,
Steven Mercer
 38501
author: Various

text:
Dear FCC,
My name is Caitlin Shortelle and I live in West Hartford , CT.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because ISPs could act as the gatekeepers to their
subscribers.
The Internet is important to me because, as a working class American it is the true 
final frontier in which your income does not prevent you from access to any 
particular thing. If those who pay to subscribe to an ISP have greater access to the
majority of the internet and it's users that would drastically affect what we are 
able to do with it now. It would effectively turn the internet into another 
situation of the haves and have nots. Please do not ruin the last social equalizer 
we have left.
Sincerely,
Caitlin Shortelle

Given that ISPs enjoy the protections of common carriers, such as not being liable 
for content, they should be defined as common carriers in the eyes of the law.
Both as a Comcast customer and a taxpayer, I do not want internet content delivered 
to me at different speeds.

The though that cable companies can even further fuel the monopoly that they already have makes me want to shit in a
bucket and then throw that bucket full of shit on my mother and then, over the course of the next 48 hours, lick that shit
off of her. It's absurd and unacceptable. Keep Net Neutrality and quit bumfucking each other over trying to pry more
money out of us and the companies that have our best interests in mind. It's not like we pay more for our internet than
any other fucking country at a lower speed than fucking Syria. North Korea's internet is provided by one hamster on a
fucking wheel and it's still fucking faster than my hulu account.
Sincerely,
Jordan Roy

individuals to equal access to the internet. It is critical that the Federal 
Communications Commission reclassify Internet Service Providers as Common Carriers, 
to eliminate the technicality whereby providers now have the ability to favor 
certain ISP traffic at their discretion for whatever reason they choose. There 
should be no favoritism in service provision- this is one area where the playing 
field needs to be level at all costs. We already live in a "Big Brother" age and the
implications for intellectual freedom are ominous if the USA does not make this 
correction.

gone through.

Dear FCC,
My name is Juan Goodwin and I live in Evansdale, IA.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because ISPs could act as the gatekeepers to their

The Internet is important to me because, as a college business student, I need to 
know that there will not be barriers to entry for the new ideas and services that I 
hope to bring to the marketplace. If ISP subscribers have an easier time loading 
websites of existing companies than my new innovative product, there?s no way that I

text:
Dear FCC,
My name is John Gerritzen and I live in Centreville, VA.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The internet, since its inception, has been a utility for sharing knowledge, 
experience, and contact. Limiting the ways people can interact on the internet, by 
way of monetary power, is a means of segregating people based on wallet-size. 
Moreover, it limits the amount of innovation that can be achieved through the 
internet.
Consider if net neutrality were not in existence in the early years of the internet.
You're a man named Larry Page, and you and your friend, Sergey Brin have the crazy idea of letting people search the internet for relevant tags, rather than having to find new websites by chance. This is the story of Google, which I'm sure, dear reader, you've used more than once in your lifetime. Google didn't monetize until later in its lifecycle, through sponsored links and their AdSense utility. Had net neutrality not been in place, Google may not have seen the light of day, and become the powerhouse it is today.
In short, if you do away with net neutrality, you do away with opportunity, the opportunity for people to innovate, create, and make the internet better for everyone that uses it, not just those with enough spending power to access certain websites reliably. The future of the internet is in your hands, and I fear we stand to lose what was once a good thing if the proper action is not taken.
Sincerely,
John Gerritzen

like of TWC and Comcast.
Please continue net neutrality.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

Chairman Tom Wheeler

text:
Dear FCC,
My name is Tim Alfieri and I live in West harrison, NY.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The Internet is important to me because, as a college business student, I need to 
know that there will not be barriers to entry for the new ideas and services that I 
hope to bring to the marketplace. If ISP subscribers have an easier time loading 
websites of existing companies than my new innovative product, there?s no way that I
will be able to compete or succeed.
Sincerely,
Tim Alfieri
FCC, support an open Internet. Do not undermine Net Neutrality!

I am a senior software engineer and have worked in the Internet industry for 
decades.  I am writing to prevent the FCC from making a terrible mistake, that is, 
to empower individual corporate entities that own the wires and servers  to 
determine what communications gets through based on how much their customers pay. 
If you enact such policy, then:
* You prevent a free market from occurring. Younger companies with newer business 
models will get their Internet traffic thwarted by pre-existing companies. 
* You will lock America into one of the slowest broadband networks in the world, 
building an enormous monopoly controlling the nation's digital eco-system.
Such a policy would entrench a Mafioso-style racket in which anyone wanting to do 
business on the Internet will need to pay up or suffer the consequences.
This is a disaster for communication and business as we know it. 
Insist that the fees for Internet and data access be the same for all entrants. The 
Internet is not Cable TV or Pay-Per-View TV. If you treat it as such, you will destroy it and the economy will suffer.

The Internet has brought both mass prosperity to our American economy. 
How? Why? 
The answer is NET NEUTRALITY. 
NET NEUTRALITY has allowed internet startups to compete with established brands and 
bring innovation to the private sector. Passing anti-NET NEUTRALITY would severely 
damage America's ability to compete and maintain our innovation in a globalized 
marketplace. Passing this legislation is just wrong economically for the future of 
the American ingenuity...
...and you're not anti-American, are you?

text:
Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
In your upcoming NPRM rules I’m very concerned about any “pay-to-play” rule, destroying Net neutrality principles is
not acceptable. This new rule will change the nature of the equal and open internet, while creating real barriers to entry
that will prohibit innovation.
I ask that you ensure Net neutrality principles are of the utmost importance, and anything violating those principles is
unacceptable to the American public and dangerous to innovators. The FCC should use its authority to regulate the
internet as a telecommunications service to protect consumers and enshrine Net neutrality.
Sincerely,
leslie Edwards
 49251

work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.

is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.

company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
I ask that you protect Net neutrality by urging the FCC to scrap the proposed “pay-to-play” rule.
This rule does more than promote the corporatization of internet access--it relegates independent sites to an inferior
internet on the ‘slow lane’ and creates a HUGE barrier to entry for new start ups that may compete with--or directly
challenge--incumbent technologies and corporations. This rule will KILL start-up innovation and enshrine the power of

broadband under title II.

text:
Keep the Internet open! The internet has worked wonderfully over the past 15+ years.
Whether you are rich, poor, young or old, the Internet allows all people to seek out
information and communicate globally.. To allow companies like Comast, TWC, and 
Verizon to charge for a fast lane would deteriote the internet and the chance for 
competition for many startups and individuals who do not necessarily have the funds 
to pay for a "fast lane." This also gives even more power to ISPs that already have 
enough power and control. 
Let's throw out the rules that Tom Wheeler has proposed and reclassify the ISPs as 
common carriers.

A two tier internet would bring inequality to the internet, preventing startups and 
small businesses from getting to customers with the same efficiency as larger firms.
It's the antithesis of competition and free markets.
Please redefine ISPs as Title 2 common carriers

Recently I have read a few articles regarding net neutrality. As far as I understand, the FCC plans on changing it's
regulations which could potentially end net neutrality, causing not only a drastic change in the way we use the internet,
but potentially a drastic uproar from the millions of internet users in the United States. I understand that these changes
are good in theory, and the FCC probably believes that these changes could create healthy competition in the digital
markets, but I feel as though the FCC has failed to realize the potential, and almost certain, negative affects that could
come from these changes in regulations.
     Sadly, internet service providers are very scares in many parts of the country. Many regions are limited to only one
provider. If these internet providers were able to discriminate against certain online services the consumers could do
absolutely nothing about it. I feel like the changes proposed by the FCC could potentially benefit the internet, and create
 healthy competition in the future, but at the moment there are simply not enough ISP options to allow ISPs the right to
discriminate, which also violates the 14th amendment of the Constitution since the Supreme Court has ruled in the past
that corporations should be treated as people.
author: Various

text:
Please do not touch net neutrality. Net neutrality is the guarantee that anything on
the internet has equal rights, and by allowing the ISPs to charge us for this "fast 
lanes"  would mean bigger companies would be able to offer better service tan 
smaller ones and startups. Which wouldn't be fair.
And when you have a look at the reasons ISPs want fast lanes it gets worse. All they
want is to not have to improve their infrastructures, so they want to limit how much
broadband you can consume (unless they get paid even more of course, either by you 
or by netflix or whoever). What's worse, fastlanes would destroy competition between
their services and external ones.
Personally it terrifies me to think that what could happen in the USA could come to 
my country. So just don't kill net neutrality. Please.

As a librarian, I deal with providing access to information to people on a daily 
basis. An open internet allows for all the ability to contribute and creates a 
competitive marketplace for ideas, where everyone can be both a producer and 
consumer of information. Favoring those who can pay over those who cannot tampers 
with that marketplace. Unleveling this playing field, divides the producers from 
consumers and gives an unfair advantage to those who currently have over those who 
do not. It stratifies society. If there is a great thing about the internet it is 
its ability to change rapidly. Favoring the voices of some over others reduces the 
that dynamic quality and hampers the democracy/free market quality of the internet. 
It is not worth giving a few a larger slice of the pie if it means reducing the size
of the pie for everyone.
Keep rfdtv it is one of the most decent tv stations left in the country

May 6, 2014
Chairman Tom Wheeler
Dear Chairman Wheeler,
As an Illinois consumer who depends on a fast, affordable web
connection, I am concerned that a free and open Internet is now in
grave danger.
We are troubled by reports that the Federal Communications Commission
(FCC) plans to propose new rules that would open the door for big
Internet providers to offer a "fast lane" to the highest
bidders. Such a proposal would water down consumer protections, serve
as a slippery slope to discrimination against certain web traffic, and
force consumers like me to suffer higher rates and slower speeds.
That violates the spirit of "net neutrality."
Please, stand up for consumers, protect net neutrality, and fight for
the free and open Internet.
Sincerely,
Ms. Margaret Dolan

Niles, IL 60714-5807

competition, innovation and allow a select few companies to form monopolies that 
will will greatly increase the cost and decrease the content available to consumers.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.

company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves

to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.

Dear FCC,
My name is Kieran Redmond and I live in East Moriches, NY.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The internet is important to me because of how important it is to our culture and 
economy. So much innovation takes place over the internet and with the removal of 
net neutrality the ability to innovate will be stifled. Giving ISPs too much control
can put a choke chain on what is a free and creative entity that os perpetually

truly free frontiers in this world.

Kieran Redmond

process of committing by allowing a "pay-to-play" option over the internet. I'll summarize because, as I mentioned

"super highway" access. This is a cost I can guarantee you will trickle down - in fact, there's your trickle down
economics we all keep hearing about. How do you expect the masses to afford this additional cost? You cannot bleed a
turnip, sir. One more thing you need to consider - your support of the very institutions that stand to benefit from this are,

interest?

forward. You can expect calls for your resignation if you decide not to heed the voice of the public. The choice is yours.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.

company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves

to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.

Honorable FCC Commission Members,
Thank you for this open comment period.
As an entrepreneur with a small ecommerce business in a market dominated by giants, 
a future world under a priority paid bandwidth system would likely force the closure
of my business.  More likely, I never would have started it.
I ask you to think not in terms of ?blocking? access, or ?bifurcating? the 
marketplace, but rather in terms of all the myriad implications the advantage of 
speed itself offers.  It?s about much more than how long it takes to download a 
movie, it?s also the ability to make known that any content supported by multimedia 
even exists, even for ordinary commerce categories.
We live in a search engine-driven world.  All content is accessed via search.  While
search algorithms are confidential trade secrets, it?s widely believed that download
speed is a critical signal that search engines like Google use in determining the 
rank order for results.  Google?s interest is having satisfied users who trust the 
links, and if immediacy of gratification is part of that user satisfaction equation,
then Google will weigh it in ranking organic results.
Therefore innovative startups challenging established giants would effectively have a double burden ? not just the burden of requiring users to be more patient for identical content, also the burden of having to overcome a search rank handicap.  Between the two, the long term burden of the search rank handicap may actually be far greater and more difficult to overcome, effectively stifling innovation even in commodity industries.   
As an example, my ecommerce website offers custom-made home furnishings.  having rich photography and an engaging presentation is vital in building consumer trust for an expensive purchase.  In a world of priority payments, giant furniture chains with deep pockets can make their pages richer, and/or deliver them faster, and as a direct result they will consistently rank higher on search results, and thereby havean enormous competitive advantage.  Even if I have a higher quality offering at a lower price, it will be significantly harder for me to just reach the marketplace inthe sense that consumers who click on a link above mine will see or know of my link?s existence. 
Search experts affirm it?s impossible to overstate the far-reaching implications of even a small speed advantage.  
Therefore, the core of this issue is not about bifurcation of the marketplace, but the formidable barriers to competitive entry and therefore innovation that even a small speed advantage brings.
It?s hard to imagine a fairness doctrine that justifies such an imbalanced system onthe basis of ability to pay for access to the marketplace itself.  It?s harder to imagine where we?d be tomorrow without the innovative startups of yesterday who enjoyed the benefit of an open marketplace to achieve their greatness of today, (talkin?bout you, netflix!).  
Some may say the night sky would be just as grand with only a few stars of super brightness, collectively shining with the same luminocity.  I suggest the night sky is unspeakably more wonderous, more enchanting, more inviting, more mysterious, moreinspiring, more harmonious, and ultimately better for humankind now and in the future with infinite variability.  
Thank you again for allowing this open comment period for this critical matter that may very well determine the survival of the innovation economy itself, the engine ofAmerican prosperity for generations.
Respectfully, 

Evan Saks
Needham, MA

Equal access to the internet is a key in providing citizens with the resources they need to be equal citizens in this country. We would never consider electricity as anoption for certain segments of the country. Nor should we consider equal access and use of the internet to be on a case-by-case basis based on what the player can afford.

The wonderful and unique level playing field that the internet provides for all data
to be treated equally is what is making it such a strong tool that is used by so 
many for so many different reasons. Any steps that our government may take towards 
diluting net neutrality is solely in the best interests of larger entities, and is 
in no way in the best interests of individuals, who the government is supposed to be
working for. There is no excuse to give in to the demands or desires of these 
corporations, and everyone knows better than to take their current reasons for 
lobbying for these changes at face value. Adapting any of the proposed changes which
threaten net neutrality would be a failure by the FCC of the highest order.
Reclassify The Internet As A Common Carrier.

Having one internet where all data is treated equally is vital. We should not give 
the monopoly providers the option to have a "fast" internet for important clients 
and a "slow" internet for the rest. 
Yes, one can wonder why the average user could want more speed. If this is permitted
to happen, in 15 years the unimportant internet clients will be struggling along 
with the equivalent of a 56k modem connection.

Dear FCC,
My name is Mariya Chechina and I live in Maywood, NJ.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The Internet is important to me because, as a college business student, I need to 
know that there will not be barriers to entry for the new ideas and services that I 
hope to bring to the marketplace. If ISP subscribers have an easier time loading 
websites of existing companies than my new innovative product, there?s no way that I
will be able to compete or succeed.
Sincerely,
Mariya Chechina
Page 1

Dear FCC,
My name is Adam Moliski and I live in Pequot Lakes, MN.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
This classification is important to me because, as a consumer, I have no other way 
to have a say on my ISP's policies. If Charter decides to put content in a 'Slow 
Lane', there is nothing I can do about it. ISPs are local monopolies, so we can't 
take our business to better providers, and giving up the internet entirely is no 
longer a viable option. 
Allowing ISPs to act as gatekeepers will do nothing but hurt consumers while padding
the pockets of the ISPs who are already charging massive markups.
Sincerely,
Adam Moliski

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
I urge you to protect the open internet by reclassifying broadband under Title II to protect Net neutrality, and by
scraping any proposed “pay-to-play” rule.
Net neutrality principles are essential to a 21st century internet. The FCC should protect the open internet and further,
treat it as a telecommunications service to disincentivize greedy ISPs from trying to extract additional fees from
consumers and web content creators.
Please protect real Net neutrality to ensure a thriving economy and democracy.
Sincerely,
Susen Shapiro
 08215

I am a software engineer with two degrees in my field from the Massachusetts 
Institute of Technology and over a decade of academic research and field experience 
behind me on making large bodies of institutional data available to the public.  The
FCC's proposed rules would certainly negatively impact my field and the small 
business I work for; we are none of us possessed of the deep pockets required to buy
into a fast lane, effectively blocking our efforts to promote one of our primary 
objectives and incentives, to make the acquisition and processing of large sets of 
data more universally accessible to all.  We won't be able to even if the cause is 
worthy, even if we wanted to.  There are similar, wider repercussions I anticipate 
have been covered exhaustively by others.
Please drop the effort to enact these rules and move to regulate connectivity as a 
public utility.  Put simply, our country's technological future should not be caught
in the inflxible grasp of the owners of the plumbing; ask them to catch us up to the
rest of the world instead.

Chairman Wheeler,
The telecom industry should not be allowed to dictate regulatory policy for an Internet that has become a basic utility
for citizens of the 21st century. Your enthusiastic complicity in the throttling of communications for the benefit of your
former industry bosses is a conflict of interest that spits in the face of the trust placed in you as a public servant. Listen
to the the public's demand for net neutrality, and heed our call for you to resign as FCC chairman.
-MS

Dear Chairman Wheeler,
As an Illinois consumer who depends on a fast, affordable web
connection, I am concerned that a free and open Internet is now in
grave danger.
We are troubled by reports that the Federal Communications Commission
(FCC) plans to propose new rules that would open the door for big

text:
I have heard about the strong desire for companies to be able to use information 
about where a person is surfing the web, or what games they play, or what they use 
their internet for primarily, and allow them to have people charge for those 
services in order to provide them better internet usage for those sites in 
particular. However, I have increasingly strong concerns over this.
My first concern is the potential for abuse. What I am talking about is the 
potential that internet companies will have, once this is in place, to look at a 
site that a person has used only once and then ask them to pay for using this site. 
That they can go into a person's history before this ruling has been placed, look at
every site they have ever been to, and charge them accordingly for every site, 
potentially accruing the debt charged to an amount that the person cannot pay for. 
Not legally being able to pay for a service rendered means great financial trouble 
and potential legal proceedings against them. This does not just affect me. Please 
realize the amount of people who go surfing the internet on Google and find sites 
pertaining to information they want to find, or people who scour the web looking for
different sites that pertain to videos, products, games, etc. 
Secondly, this destroys the chances that anyone will get their website off the 
ground. With people being charged to be able to access a website, people become verychoosy with who they go to. It hurts the business of these sites. YouTube would takea hard hit if people were charged to use it, Amazon would take a hard hit as people head out to find items at their local stores instead of paying, google would take a hit as people find a different way to find the information rather than having to pay. Internet companies in general would take a hit as people tried to avoid using the internet as much as possible.
There are other concerns but I feel that this is enough...please, I would advise youto heavily reconsider this. I speak not just for myself but for the whole of the internet, do not implement this decision. It will only serve to hurt the internet, companies who provide the internet, and people who use the internet.

Dear Mr. Wheeler,
I implore you to listen to the variety of voices that are crying out for the necessity of net neutrality. It is imperative that
the internet remain free and open, with little to no influence from ISPs who already have such a monopoly as service
providers.
Without net neutrality, Facebook would have never happened. Not to mention successful businesses like Netflix and
Hulu. The internet is the greatest tool for free speech, and by either allowing a fast lane (or inversely a slow lane) which
creates preferential treatment is the worst thing that could happen to the free market.
I demand net neutrality. So do so many others.
Listen to them, or we will demand your resignation.
--
Ryan Stong
Huntington Beach, CA

My name is Ashley Clauson and I live in Monroe , WA.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it 
users may have fewer options and a less diverse Internet.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

Sincerely,
Nicholas Matula.

In my opinion, I feel it would greatly undermine our personal freedoms if the 
two-tier system would be allowed to operate.   This would cause enormous increases 
to associated costs of service as well as a decrease in content availability.   I 
would further like to suggest that by placing a former lobbyist in charge of the fcc

Reclassify broadband internet as a title II common carrier telecommunications 
service.

To whom it may concern,
I have serious concerns about the FCC's proposal to continue to regulate broadband Internet access service providers
(ISPs) as information services.
I do not believe the transparency rule provides enough information for consumers to make informed choices.  With the
no-unreasonable-discrimination rule vacated, an ISP can negotiate any secret deal it wishes with any or all content
providers (CPs) to extract payment for the use the ISP's network and there is no way for a consumer to know the details
or even necessarily that such a deal exists.
Even if a consumer could learn all the details of the discrimination arrangements between all ISPs and CPs, I do not
believe that the ISP industry represents a viable market.  For consumers, transitioning from one ISP to another is
difficult or, in many cases, impossible because only a single ISP exists in their area.  Certainly one cannot choose ISP A
for consuming services from CP X and ISP B for consuming services from CP Y without having simply paid for the full
 suite of services from every ISP.
I find the notion that ISPs can collect twice for the same data delivery repugnant and not in keeping with the common
notion that a consumer who has paid for a service to deliver data at a certain rate must now pay again (through higher
costs passed on by the CP) to make anything available to deliver.
I also find compelling the argument Ryan Singel makes (https://medium.com/p/7805f8049503) that if unfair terms are
imposed by an ISP on a CP, that the ISPs wield enough power to delay any judgment long enough to irreparably harm
the profitability of a CP, and that even if a judgment is rendered in the CP's favor, an appeal could result in a court again
 ruling that the FCC has overstepped its authority.
My recommendations are:
*       I believe the FCC does have the authority to dictate terms more in keeping with the notion of an Open Internet and
 that the only way it can effectively exercise that authority without the courts whittling away at it or outright overturning
 it is to reclassify ISPs as common carriers.
*       If the FCC cannot see fit to reclassify ISPs, the transparency rule should be explicitly expanded to eliminate secret
dealing between ISPs and CPs and thus make the costs of using particular CPs visible to consumers.  Even if genuine
competition is unavailable or impractical, the potential still exists for the ISPs to respond to public shaming via such
transparency.
Best Regards,
Keith Chapman
22305 Canterfield Way
Germantown, MD

There are too few places left in the capitalist world that are still considered true
free markets - the internet is the last frontier! The ability to connect people with
infinite information is extremely powerful. To provide the small oligopoly with 
exclusive access to this power is dangerous. The free exchange of ideas and the 
principle that anyone with the right idea and the courage to share it can be 
successful are core to our values as a nation. It is disheartening to think that our
government would create barriers to entry to serve the few at the expense of the 
many. The internet is a public good - just like parks. Imagine if people were 
required to pay a premium to access parks, so that 2-3 playground equipment 
manufacturers could profit from a public good. It doesn't add up. Please, protect 
the digital public work of the internet.

text: Reclassify broadband internet as a common carrier telecommunications service.

Dear FCC,
My name is Ahren Norbert Gutschenritter and I live in Wichita, KS.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it I 
may never be able to start up a internet software business that I have been wanting 
to do since I started learning to program.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The Internet is important to me. It has become an open source for information that 
has changed people's lives and has given birth to great ideas and innovations. 
Places like Facebook, where I can stay connected with my friends and family, Amazon,
the place I can buy items I want, and Wikipedia, the site that has kept a compendium
of all human knowledge. The Internet has produced amazing things and now since the 
new Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling, I am absolutely stunned. It is 
despicable to think that the government has been complicit in allowing a corporate, 
anti free-market, crony takeover of this great innovation that has been absolutely essential in paving the way for new technologies. It is horrendous that this administration has elected a telecommunications lobbying blowhard to run the FCC, anagency that demands absolute fairness for oversight.
The Internet has worked perfectly and will work perfectly if the current model of net neutrality is maintained. To clarify, the new ruling would allow telecommunications companies to charge premiums for the service that everyone is guaranteed now. It is economically unsound as it would stunt starts up and capital and ultimately stunt potential economic growth. Not only that, but information wouldbe accessible at lower quality and would give unprecedented power to what these companies believe to proper content or not. Freedom of information is a right. It's not something up for debate. People have the right to freedom of speech and expression, along with the pursuit of knowledge.
I would like to wrap this up by invoking an old proverb: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."  Please, don't give into these corporate crony crooks who think they know what THEY think is important. Do the right thing and keep Net Neutrality.
Sincerely,
Ahren Norbert Gutschenritter

Dear FCC,

Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it The 
internet would loose so much of its power as a place of opportunity and freedom! 
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
As a young person working on a few startups, I need to know my sites can garner real
traffic! And as an Internet user, I feel it only ethical that my searches bring up 
the actual best match, not influenced by what companies have paid for! 
Sincerely,
Torrey Burke-Weeks
