Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

If any US representative engages in promoting this idea, they need to be removed 
from office.  WE THE PEOPLE do NOT support this action.  NET NEUTRALITY MUST BE 
PRESERVED. PERIOD.
DO NOT proceed.  Anyone involved should be dealt with as criminal charges and 
malfesance in office.
STOP DO NOT DO IT.

text:
Dear Chairman Tom,
Over the past two decades, the Internet has flourished and revolutionized our lives precisely because it has remained
free of government overregulation.  Recently, however, Obama's Federal Communications Commission (FCC) proposed
 new rules that could reclassify broadband Internet as a monopoly-era plain old telephone service of decades past (aka
common carrier telecommunications service) under Title II of the Communications Act.
Simply put, the federal government micromanaging the Internet is a dangerous scheme, one that Congress must halt and
 the FCC must abandon.  As a concerned citizen, I urge you to do everything in your power to stop any and all efforts by
 the FCC to reclassify broadband Internet under Title II of the Communications Act.
Sincerely,
Robert Wilson
116 Bogey Cir
Comanche, TX 76442

Dear FCC,
My name is Halee Young and I live in Walling, TN.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because ISPs could act as the gatekeepers to their
subscribers.
The Internet is important to me as a recent graduate with a degree in foreign 
language. I need to know that there will be no barriers to entry for the existing 
services and sites that I use to keep my level of language as well as no barriers 
for any future opportunity which I may be able to offer the worldwide web to assist 
in continued language study. This does not mention the radical changes that my 
hobbies may face, which is another thing I am not quite happy about. My brain may 
stagnate if I am unable to effectively research my language or my hobbies and this 
will limit my ability to be a productive US citizen as I will not be able to innovate within the market. This decision seems to gives ISPs absolute power and thesaying goes that absolute power corrupts absolutely. This does not even encompass all the events that are possible with this decision, as it is only the complaint of one small person, but I implore you to please consider all the ramifications of sucha landmark decision and the effects it will have on present and future generations. I know I am not the only one; read all the letters and consider all that has been said. Please support Net neutrality. 
Sincerely,
Halee Young

text:
Net neutrality is an issue that is vital to liberty and fairness to all Americans. I
urge you to do the right thing.

May 6, 2014
Chairman Tom Wheeler
Dear Chairman Wheeler,
As an Illinois consumer who depends on a fast, affordable web
connection, I am concerned that a free and open Internet is now in
grave danger.
We are troubled by reports that the Federal Communications Commission
(FCC) plans to propose new rules that would open the door for big
Internet providers to offer a "fast lane" to the highest
bidders. Such a proposal would water down consumer protections, serve
as a slippery slope to discrimination against certain web traffic, and
force consumers like me to suffer higher rates and slower speeds.
That violates the spirit of "net neutrality."
Please, stand up for consumers, protect net neutrality, and fight for
the free and open Internet.
Sincerely,
Ms. Donna Carlson
PO Box 355
Woodhull, IL 61490-0355

text:
Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

Net neutrality reflects the principles on which this country was founded. We must 
protect an open internet, not allowing two speeds of delivery for different content 
based on premium payers and those who do not pay the premium.

Please write your own message of support for Net Neutrality here.
Net equality please
--
Courtney Schlessiger
United States of America

Neutrality. In addition, the FCC should reject the proposed rules that would allow Internet service
providers to divide the Internet into fast lanes for wealthy corporations and slow lanes for the rest of
us.

Sincerely,

Francis Schanberger
104 Bonner Street, Dayton, Ohio
Dayton, OH 45410-1306

CREDO Action

I am Cody, I am 17 and I would like you to reclassify broadband internet as a common
carrier telecommunications service.

The FCC should protect net neutrality by reclassifying broadband providers as common
carriers under Title II.

Please reconsider granting our internet providers additional control over how they 
provide their services. We are already dismally slow and expensive compared to 
everywhere else in the world--which is a TRAVESTY in and of itself--please don't 
make us even more of a laughing stock, and please don't shaft American consumers 
even more than we already are being shafted. It's bad enough that competition is 
non-existent in this environment of government-sanctioned monopoly, please please 
please don't make it worse for us. In fact, maybe consider doing the OPPOSITE of 
what you have planned and work to make our internet service better in this country 
instead of worse. Profits aren't everything--and, as the rest of the world has 
proven where the internet is concerned, the opposite is true.

Please do not allow the cable companies to control the access to internet speed or 
service. 
This would only allow for LESS competition and WORSE service from the telecom 
companies.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

speed of content is essentially the same as access. The Internet is the foundation

class system. .
PROTECT NET NEUTRALITY FOR THE PEOPLE

The people have spoken loudly, and we want net neutrality!  Nothing else will suffice.  You have a responsibility to
protect the digital commons for the people of this country.  Instead, you propose ineffective regulations and mouth
platitudes that are meant to mollify us,  with the end result being that cable and telecomm companies will have the keys
to the Internet.  Is this the legacy that you want?  You have a real choice to make:  stand up for the people and a
democratic Internet, or cozy up to Big Telecommunications.
I still have hope that you will do the right thing.

Dear FCC,
My name is Susie Garibay and I live in Chicago, IL.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better

text:
From: alexrwilliam@gmail.com
To:
Tom.Wheeler@fcc.gov;Mignon.Clyburn@fcc.gov;Jessica.Rosenworcel@fcc.gov;Ajit.Pai@fcc.gov;Mike.ORielly@fcc.
gov
Date: 5/16/2014 11:35
Subject: Net Neutrality Proposal
To the Commissioners,
I urge you to reconsider the instatement of Mr. Wheeler's proposal on net neutrality.
The United States is already a dangerously closed-off country from information from the rest of the world. 90% of our
news media comes from none but 5 large corporations who hold interests in hundreds of national and international
business interests. It is appalling that these 5 corporations control the information that the majority of the public digests,
as most people would most likely not take the time to seek less biased information elsewhere. This is a country in which
 corporations have had so much power through clever marketing lobbying and other forms of questionable political
influence that we have managed to convince a good part of the population that a scientific FACT of climate change is
false. So instead of changing the situation for the better of our future we manipulated lied to our people so that our
interests in oil could continue to make enormous profits.
This is a country in which it is so easy to tell lies to people so that our business interests will not be harmed. Another
example (of hundreds more), is the NRA convincing people that the Arms Trade Treaty will take away domestic
weapons and the country's inability to pass a simple background check for acquiring weapons, which an overwhelming
majority of the country supported. These are the corporations and organizations that control the information we digest.
The internet remains our last source for sharing information without any filtration. The younger generations who grew
up with the internet are not bound to close-minded perspectives confined to the contaminated information we receive
from common news sources. The internet must remain entirely free and open and should not by any means have a
gatekeeper with ulterior motives. If we allow corporations such as Comcast and At&t to determine the speed of the
information we receive, this is one step closer to Soviet era state in which the populations no longer has no access to
unbiased information, and there will be countless loopholes in which the ISPs can build unjust monopolies and hurt start
 up companies and competition.
Though you may be prohibiting ISPs from slowing down internet right now, internet speeds have risen over the years.
And in a few years time only those with priority access will have internet speeds that match what the standard should
be.
I find it disconcerting that the person who has introduced this proposal used to lobby for those corporations. There
seems to be an interest in this proposal for Mr. Wheeler with his ties from his previous years as a lobbyist. Despite the
tremendous public outcry through tens of thousands of protestors, more than 100 of the nation's most important
companies, and millions who have signed petitions against this proposal, your commission has voted to move forward
with this proposal. It is CLEAR what the country's majority stance is on this issue. There is no question that if this were
a true democracy the proposal would be off the table. I urge you to consider this and take a truly democratic approach
when considering this proposal.
 I cannot quite grasp how a group of 5 people have total control over an issue that directly affects 320 million people,
who have no way to cast a vote other than to "comment" on the FCC website. But this is another issue with our so-called
 democratic system. I hope you shut down this proposal, as it would be a huge leap in the wrong direction.
Sincerely,
Alexander Richard Williamson
United States
author: Various

CREDO Action

Public access to a neutral internet is one of the most important issues of our era, 
perhaps right behind campaign finance reform. And as we've seen, there is truly a 
slippery slope once money can purchase power. Moreover, when you allow entities to 
purchase influence through elections or media, it is an unacceptable encroachment 
upon the very premise that underpins Democracy--an informed citizenry. Despite the 
potential interpretation of your agencies guiding principles that may allows you to 
rule in favor of this mistake, please consider the ramifications that your ruling 
may have and consider how technical misbehavior can change public sentiment about an
agency or program--the healthcare website come to mind.

I believe in a fully open and egalitarian internet where all users have equal and 
open access. No one company or ISP should be allowed to give special treatment to 
one person, company, or class of people. A free and fully open internet is vital to 
our democracy. Allowing ISPs to provide preferential treatment to anyone is like 
allowing them to cordon off the public square where citizens meet to govern 
themselves. It promotes inequality and the ability of the powerful to subjugate the 
masses. Keep the internet free and accessible to all.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.
Reclassify Internet Service Providers As Common Carriers.

text:
I am a small business owner that operates on the internet.  In a world where everything is getting faster and faster, I can
not afford to have my websites load slowly.  Website visitors expect pages to load quickly and easily.  If there are
delays in my pages loading, I could lose those customers.
My customers pay for their internet service. I pay for my internet and for my website hosting, and having to pay even
more money to be on a "top tier" or "fast lane" for internet would be devastating to my business.
We need to have NET NEUTRALITY. Don't allow the big service providers to play the "PAY to PLAY" game!

text:
Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

The Internet is important not just to me, or to any one company. It is fundamental 
to the future of the American economy. I need to know that there will not be 
barriers to entry for the new ideas and services that I hope are brought to the 
marketplace. If ISP subscribers have an easier time loading websites of existing 
companies than one with a new, innovative product, there's no way that the 
incredible dynamism of the increasingly important information technology sector of 
the American economy can be sustained. I strongly urge you to reclassify Internet 
Service Providers as Title II Common Carriers, a long overdue and much needed 
regulatory change. 
Please don't let the free flow of information, something so essential to our 
development as people and as a nation, be manipulated so blatantly. Our country's 
future depends on it.
Reclassify broadband internet as a common carrier telecommunications service.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––
I ask that you protect Net neutrality by urging the FCC to scrap the proposed “pay-to-play” rule.
This rule does more than promote the corporatization of internet access--it relegates independent sites to an inferior
internet on the ‘slow lane’ and creates a HUGE barrier to entry for new start ups that may compete with--or directly
challenge--incumbent technologies and corporations. This rule will KILL start-up innovation and enshrine the power of
Big Telecom, who will make the internet as awful as cable television.
Please protect Net neutrality to preserve an open internet and urge the FCC to assert reclassification authority of
broadband under title II.
Sincerely,
Anita Ciannilli
 13206

Tom Wheeler
Dear Chaiman Wheeler:
     I am writing today to urge you to reject Chairman Tom Wheeler's
proposal to allow internet service providers (ISP) to charge different
rates for faster access to websites willing to pay, or to allow any
discretion on the part of ISPs to mange the flow of information on the
internet based on who the information provider is, or their willingness to
pay for access.
     The internet was founded on the principle of net neutrality. And the
success of that principle speaks for itself. There is no reason to allow
ISPs to manage the flow of information on the internet to maximize their
profits to the detriment of every other stakeholder in the internet.
     Please reject Chairman Wheeler's proposal, and any other proposal
that diverges from the principle of net neutrality.
Sincerely,
Janie Russ

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.
Please keep the internet open and fair to all companies.

Dear FCC,
My name is Julia Kenny and I live in Wilmington, NC.
Net neutrality, the principle that Internet service providers (ISPs) treat all data 
that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
The Internet is very important to me because, as a college student who works hard to
stay updated and informed about the world in which I live, the internet is an 
invaluable resource that is a necessity for the modern citizen. Taking away net 
neutrality is a major step backwards for society. Everyone should be able to access 
information on the internet equally. A person's salary has no right to determine 
what information they can access.
Sincerely,
Julia Kenny

Please declare the Internet a common carrier and regulate it as such. It's clear that Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T are
trying to put one over on the public.
As the Consumerist points out, "While the Verizons and Comcasts of the world like to pretend that they do all of the
heavy lifting in bringing data to your home, the truth is often very different. In most cases, an ISP is only responsible for
 carrying data the 'last mile' to the end-user. There are numerous bandwidth providers who do much of the long-distance
 hauling of data.
"Much of the innovation and investment that the NCTA claims will be harmed by reclassification has actually been
done by companies much further up the stream than your ISP. Verizon is not responsible for figuring out to compress
and stream HD Netflix videos to millions of customers at once. AT&T did not create the smartphones or tablets its
subscribers use. Comcast is not running multiplayer video game servers that allow players from around the world to
square off in real time. ISPs are passive (and increasingly passive-aggressive) conduits through which this data is
supposed to travel as efficiently as possible and with no regard for its source."
The Consumerist continues, "Allowing ISPs to decide which content gets to users the fastest — and making this
decision based not on the most efficient way to deliver data, but solely on who pays the most — is like handing over
highway exit ramps to a private toll-taking company and telling it to charge whatever it wants to drivers looking to get
on or off the Interstate." http://consumerist.com/2014/05/14/lets-dissect-the-cable-industrys-b-s-net-neutrality-argument/
We want action for democratic media, not platitudes as smokescreens for corporate domination of the Internet. We
demand Net neutrality.
Jeanine Center
618 Northside Avenue
Ann Arbor, MI 48105

Keep the internet open and unbiased toward content providers.  The issue, as I 
understand it, is how to enable carriers to recover the costs required to:
1) provide universal high-speed coverage over such a huge area (United States); and 
2) provide the infrastructure necessary to provide high-quality streaming video, as 
consumers switch to internet TV and internet movies.
The former needs to be covered by a universal fee surcharge, evenly applied to those
who don't qualify by income or local subsidy for a discount.
The latter needs to be framed as a utility charge to the consumer, not as a tool to 
extort from any content provider.  If a consumer wants to watch streaming video 
beyond, say, 20 minutes per video, then they can make that choice and pay that 
price.  A screen describing the charge visually and audibly should precede these 
longer videos.  
The principles that the FCC needs to follow is A) no censorship by extortionate fee;
and B) Consumer Choice is Inviolate !

Internet service and everyone else continues to have slower service.

that travels over their networks equally, is important to me because without it ISPs
could have too much power to determine my Internet experience by providing better 
access to some services but not others.
A pay-to-play Internet worries me because new, innovative services that can't afford
expensive fees for better service will be less likely to succeed.
We wouldn't make it more expensive to publish a book for certain people and we don't
charge people with fancy cars more to drive on the road, so why would we ever make 
it more difficult for the little guy to setup a website and earn my business? I pay 
the cable company and ISPs money to give me fast reliable service. Encourage these 
ISPs to compete on technology and service, not on packaging and arbitrary fencing of
features. This is where a free market thrives, when new and better technology is in 
demand and providing the best service. If Net Neutrality is removed, the free market
is broken and not only do customers suffer, but in the long term so will these ISPs'business. Give them the legislation they need, keep Net Neutrality.
Sincerely,
Chris McQueen

Chairman Tom Wheeler

Federal Communications Commission
445 12th Street, SW

Washington, DC 20554

Re: WC Docket No. 14-28 Comments

As an Internet user who believes strongly in the importance of a free and open Internet, I urge the
FCC to reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, and save Net
Neutrality. In addition, the FCC should reject the proposed rules that would allow Internet service
providers to divide the Internet into fast lanes for wealthy corporations and slow lanes for the rest of
us.

Sincerely,

Dean CockeI
4990 Summit St.
West Linn, OR 97068-3128

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

text:
Dear FCC,
I am writing to oppose rules that will allow for discrimination on the Internet - where the wealthy can purchase faster
Internet service and everyone else continues to have slower service.
I do not want telecom giants and wealthy Internet companies to determine the future of the Internet. I want new ideas to
flourish on the Internet and not be blocked because they do not have sufficient funds to purchase fast service and
compete.
I do not want the Internet to be turned into another vehicle that allows money to flow from working Americans to the
wealthiest -- where web-based services like Netflix purchase faster service and pass the costs on to consumers.
The proposal being considered would kill rather than protect Net Neutrality and allow rampant discrimination online.
The Internet should be viewed as a public good and should be operated consistent with our rights to Freedom of Speech
and Freedom of the Press. Turning the Internet into a pay to play scheme is unacceptable.
--
Bob Gordon
bgdg2@frontier.com

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

The internet has long been a public venue for information and communication. 
Interference from deep pocketed platforms can clamp down on innovation and restrict 
the use of the internet to those with more money. Big business would rule, 
restricting small start-ups and new innovation, where the little guy would get a 
slowed down version of business cencored information. 
Net neutrality is part of democracy and the FCC must not cave in to the interests of
corporate legislation.

text:
Dear FCC, I want to state unequivocally that "Net Neutrality" is a bad idea, that it
is bad for consumers, that it will adversely affect not only consumers but 
businesses that use the Internet, and that the only possible beneficiaries of "Net 
Neutrality" are corporations that can afford to pay for what will inevitably become 
the preferred level of internet data delivery, so, essentially, cable companies such
as Time Warner and Comcast. I do not particularly imagine that the FCC really has 
any interest whatsoever in preserving the level playing field that is the current 
Internet data delivery model, and I do not imagine that the FCC has any interest 
whatsoever in the opinions of American citizens not affiliated with a well-funded 
lobbying organization. Notwithstanding, I am obliged to make my position clear, 
since failing to do so would demonstrate as little respect for the American way as 
the FCC will likely demonstrate by enacting "Net Neutrality."

We the people ARE in favor of net neutrality.  We don't care what the large 
corporations want.  We've repeatedly voted against any actions that would stop net 
neutrality, yet now, because of large corporations, the internet is closer than ever
to being manipulated by money.  Money, money, money.  Isn't this the United States 
of America?  The land of EQUALITY.  As an internet startup, how on earth am I 
expected to compete with multi-billion dollar companies for internet bandwidth?  
This is pathetic and beyond ludicrous!

Preserving net neutrality is preserving what America and its citizens have always 
upheld as the most sacred crowning achievement: the free market.
We denounce Communism, because putting the economy into the hands of a small, 
self-serving group of individuals does not foster economic prosperity for a 
country's citizens. But whether that small, self-serving group of individuals is a 
government entity or a collection of corporate executives, the end result is the 
same; a decline in economic prosperity. 
Because of this fact, America has always opposed the existence of corporate 
monopolies. Preserving a neutral Internet will keep this necessary tradition alive.
Diversity and the division of power is the key to prosperity. It is what America was
built on, and what it should do well to remember. It is present in our citizenry, in
our government system, and, with net neutrality, in our economy.
Our citizenry is diverse. Our government system is not one part, but three. Just as 
we need a system of checks and balances in our government system, we need a system 
of checks and balances in our economy, and that system is an open and free internet;
a neutral Internet.
Please keep the Internet free and neutral.
Sincerely, 
The American Citizen
author: Jonathon McBride

Comcast famously began charging Netflix for access to its own paying customers and 
effectively ended Net Neutrality in the process.  Do the law-makers really think 
future internet startups are going to have the capital to make pay-offs to the 
corporate mob while at the same time offering a powerful and innovative service to 
the people of the internet?  You're selling out future innovation by allowing the 
existing power structure to run things the way you have.  Designate the cable 
companies as common carriers to send the message that innovation is how America 
progresses, not by throttling down services and demanding "a piece of the action" 
from the internet companies.

To Chairman Tom Wheeler and the FCC Commissioners––––

text:
Stop being a sellout and actually support what is good for the public, not what is 
good for a handful of giant corporations.  Keep net neutrality the way it is.

Net neutrality is the First Amendment of the Internet, the principle that Internet 
service providers (ISPs) treat all data equally. As an Internet user, net neutrality
is vitally important to me. The FCC should use its Title II authority to protect it.
Most Americans have only one choice for truly high speed Internet: their local cable
company. This is a political failure, and it is an embarrassment. America deserves 
competition and choice.
Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

Keep the net neutral! The cable companies are monopolies and are hijacking an 
already fair system. Again, please allow equal access and not a tiered system.

As an American citizen, I wanted to voice my opposition to the FCC?s crippling new 
regulations that would put federal bureaucrats in charge of internet freedom, and 
urge you to stop these regulations before they?re enacted.
Infrastructure upgrades will become a thing of the past, because government will 
naturally favor entrenched special interests, rather than upstart companies that can
do a better job at a cheaper price.
Like many Americans, I believe that the internet should remain free of government 
control and unnecessary regulation?just as it has for the last twenty years of 
unprecedented growth.
Please stop the FCC?s dangerous new regulations\, and protect the future of internet
freedom here in America.

text:
I urge the FCC to reject this proposed internet fast lane, and require all ISPs to 
treat all traffic on their networks the same for all customers.  In fact I urge the 
FCC to classify the internet as a utility under title 2.  
As the need for bandwidth is only going to increase, I believe over time you will 
only see the ISPs upgrades to the paid fast lane, and the regular service will be 
allowed to degrade to an unusable speed.  This is going to create a world where ever
ISP will be free to impose it's tax on the internet, and crush innovative new 
companies before they even get off the ground.  Once one company in a given sector 
pays for better access, it is only going to force everyone to pay the ISP toll, 
instead of using that money to invest in a better service and a better customer 
experience.
Reclassify broadband internet as a common carrier telecommunications service.

Net Neutrality needs to protected. The ISP's should not be allowed to control the 
flow of data in any way shape or form. If they are allowed to hinder the flow of 
information; it will be a grievous blow the the American people, American Business, 
Innovation, and Freedom. These companies keep "Promising" that they wont ruin Net 
Neutrality--the fact that such a promise even has to be made is telling. What they 
are attempting to do is /wrong/ and should not be allowed to pass. All eyes are on 
you right now; do the right thing and side with The People.

text:
Chairman Tom Wheeler

Federal Communications Commission
445 12th Street, SW

Washington, DC 20554

Re: WC Docket No. 14-28 Comments

As an Internet user who believes strongly in the importance of a free and open Internet, I urge the
FCC to reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, and save Net
Neutrality. In addition, the FCC should reject the proposed rules that would allow Internet service
providers to divide the Internet into fast lanes for wealthy corporations and slow lanes for the rest of
us.

Sincerely,

George A DaveIis
1212 Roland Drive
Papillion, NE 68046-6170

CREDO Action

I am strongly concerned by the FCC's announcement to allow so called "fast lanes". 
There are several problems with this proposal.
1. Charging on both ends, effectively ignoring speeds promised to the subscriber. 
The ISP is already charging the subscriber for a certain level of access, say 10Mbit
downstream. However, now the ISP wants to refuse to provide the service level that 
they promised and charge whoever wants to send data to the subscriber again. I.e. we
will only send your data to the subscriber at a rate of 0.5Mbit unless you pay up. 
They completely ignore the promise they made to the subscriber, which was to have 
10Mbit downstream.
2. Punishing cord cutters. Cable subscriptions are insanely lucrative, but that 
might be changing. However, this should be an isolated issue separately from 
Internet access. Sadly most ISPs are also cable providers, so now that people escape
the cable TV milking, they want to create a new cash cow by increasing the price of 
internet access and monopolizing access to subscribers like they already do in Cable
TV.
3. Freedom to do business on the web will be over. It is effectively impossible for 
a small startup without a big war chest to establish a Netflix competitor, because you won't be able to afford paying for access to the ISP's subscribers. Even if the ISPs would be open to do doing business with you, established players will lobby them to not do so. This will kill internet innovation and job creation as we know ittoday.
4. There won't be fast lanes, there will be new slow dirt roads and the existing normal speed. When the ISPs tell you about new "fast lanes", what they mean is that they will selectively stop letting these links congest over capacity. What will happen is that speed increases and investment in bigger links will seize, meaning the "normal internet" will slowly die and be slow, congested and unreliable at all times. They won't invest in new fast lanes, they will just let everything else go un/underinvested. This will contribute to killing innovation and job creation.
5. Consumers have no choice to escape this situation. There is no ISP competition, most ISP subscribers in the US have only one single choice. If their ISP starts letting service quality dwindle, to extort "fast lane" fees from companies like Netflix, they can not simply switch providers. Most consumers oppose fast lanes, butISPs will install them (just like other measures that most consumers oppose, like data caps), because they know for consumers it's either them or no internet. Further, even if a consumer has the choice of switching ISPs, the situation will look as follows. Cheap ISP A that enforces fast lanes vs sustainable ISP B that invests in his infrastructure. Most likely B will charger more, since they can't press money out of internet businesses. Now if you switch from A to B you will pay more for internet service, but you will still subsidize A by paying internet companies more money, so they can in turn pay up to ISPs like A. For example Netflixincreased their price for all subscribers worldwide, due to Comcast now pressing money for peering out of them. They did not only increase the price for Comcast subscribers. This means the pricing structure is very opaque and not clear to consumers.
The severity of a lack of innovation and can be easily illustrated. Remember 10 years ago, when you had to pay a fortune to call your aunt on that other continent? Due to a fast and easily accessible internet, companies like Skype could disrupt thetelephone market and drive down prices for end users dramatically and even offer free international calling for everyone. In a "fast lane" world, this can not happen, because the call quality will be too bad. Now keep in mind that most ISPs are also phone service providers and they would have LOVED to prevent that disruption and keep milking the consumer.
Due to the reasons given above, I strongly oppose the establishment of fast lanes and urge the FCC to go back to its original path of promoting net neutrality withoutexceptions. I also urge the FCC to break the ISP monopoly in the United States and 

ensure that real competition exists in all communities.

Please write your own message of support for Net Neutrality here.
No one should Control the internet, LEAST of all Corporate giants (small g).
--
Barson
United States of America
___
Note: Barson sent you this message as part of an Avaaz campaign to stop the corporate Internet takeover at
http://www.avaaz.org/en/us_net_neutrality_now_1/?reply. To respond, please e-mail reply+usnetneutrality@Avaaz.org

Without net neutrality, a bad situation gets even worse. These ISPs will now be able
to manipulate our Internet experience by speeding up some services and slowing down 
others. That kills choice, diversity, and quality.
It also causes tremendous economic harm. If ISPs can speed up favored services and 
slow others, new businesses will no longer be able to rely on a level playing field.
When ISPs can slow your site and destroy your business at will, how can any startup 
attract investors?
My friends, family, and I use the Internet for conversation and fun, but also for 
work and business. When you let ISPs mess with our Internet experience, you are 
attacking our social lives, our entertainment, and our economic well being. We won'tstand for it.
ISPs are opposing Title II so that they can destroy the FCC's net neutrality rules in court. This is the same trick they pulled last time. Please, let's not be fooled again. Title II is the strong, legally sound way to enforce net neutrality. Use it.

For the price of a few million dollars in lobbying, the worst companies in this 
nation will be availed many billions of dollars in shakedown money. Through such a 
scheme, Americans can be effectively force-fed whatever propaganda is desired by 
these truly terrible cartels.  Anyone doubting the awfulness of, say, Comcast need 
only contact customer service of said business:
Customer stays home for a week.  Finds that service is cut from approximately 8am to
4pm. This goes on for entire week.
Customer: Have you been turning off my service during the work day?
Customer "service": No. Is there anything else I may help you with? (During-the-day 
service returns the next day)
Removal of net neutrality is an affront to every concept of a free and open society 
ever conceived.

Do not allow cable companies to establish "fast lane"/ preferential treatments.
Preserve true net neutrality. Establish internet as a public utility, with the 
controls appropriate for a public utility.

Please don't allow the major corporations to control the internet.
Keep the internet free.
--
Rob
United States of America
___
Note: Rob sent you this message as part of an Avaaz campaign to stop the corporate Internet takeover at
http://www.avaaz.org/en/us_net_neutrality_now_1/?reply. To respond, please e-mail reply+usnetneutrality@Avaaz.org
author: Various

text:
I call on you to commit to “true” net neutrality -- “We as a nation must settle for nothing less than complete neutrality in
 our communication channels. Do not give some providers power to decide who gets a connection, or a better
connection. The world is watching what happens here to see if this country still be lives in equality, or only service to
those who can pay the most, as the world used to be before this country was invented.
Carolyn Swartz
Mesa, Arizona
author: Various

text:
I was deeply disappointed to hear that the Federal Communications Commission is planning on implementing rule
changes that would allow Internet service providers to pay for special, faster lanes to deliver their content. In an
environment where large corporations can pay for faster service, start-ups and every day Internet users won't be able to
compete and we will lose the open, free-flowing exchange of information that has made the Internet so dynamic and
integral to our lives.
The FCC can ensure it has the tools to act by reclassifying broadband as a telecommunications service. I urge you to
reject the new rules and to take this vital and common sense step toward protecting net neutrality.
Mike McVay
 98260
